title: 107_hr3160
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bioterrorism Prevention Act of 2001" and includes an expansion of the biological weapons statute. The "Bioterrorism Prevention Act of 2001" expands the biological weapons statute by amending Section 175 of title 18, United States Code to include penalties for reckless handling of select agents. This includes fines, imprisonment for up to one year, or both for those who possess, use, or control select agents in a manner that endangers public health and safety. The "Bioterrorism Prevention Act of 2001" amends Section 175 of title 18, United States Code to include penalties for violations related to biological agents or toxins. This includes fines, imprisonment for up to 10 years, or both for causing bodily injury, and fines or imprisonment for possessing unregistered select agents. The Bioterrorism Prevention Act of 2001 imposes penalties for transferring select agents without proper registration, shipping or possessing select agents illegally, with fines, imprisonment for up to 5 years, or both. The Bioterrorism Prevention Act of 2001 imposes penalties for illegal possession or transfer of select agents, with fines, imprisonment for up to 5 years, or both. Section 175 of title 18, United States Code, defines terms related to biological agents, toxins, and bodily injury for use as weapons. The Bioterrorism Prevention Act of 2001 prohibits possession of biological agents, toxins, or delivery systems for non-peaceful purposes. A 'restricted person' is defined as someone listed in section 922(g) or an alien not lawfully admitted for permanent residence.
